description: Which of the following properties are true for a max heap?
options: The root is always the largest element
Every parent node is smaller than its children
The tree must be perfectly balanced
The heap must be implemented using an array

description: For a binary heap with n nodes, what is the index of the last non-leaf node?
Match each heap concept with its correct description.

matches.Max Heap: Parent nodes are greater than children
matches.Min Heap: Parent nodes are less than children
matches.Complete Binary Tree: All levels filled except possibly last
matches.Height: Log(n) where n is number of nodes

description: In a binary heap stored in an array, for a node at index i, what are the indices of its children?
options: 2i and 2i+1
2i+1 and 2i+2
i/2 and i/2+1
i*2 and i*2+2

description: Drag these statements to order them from most fundamental to most specific heap property.
options: Must be a complete binary tree
Each node has at most two children
Parent nodes follow heap property
Can be efficiently stored in an array

description: Match the heap operations with their primary use cases.
What is the maximum number of nodes in a binary heap of height h?
Which properties must be maintained for a valid min heap?
options: Only the root must be the smallest element
Each node must be smaller than all its descendants
The tree must be balanced and sorted
Siblings must be in ascending order

description: Match each term with its corresponding heap property.
What makes a binary heap different from a binary search tree?
options: Heap must be complete, BST doesn't need to be
Heap compares parent-child, BST compares left-right
Both A and B are correct
Neither A nor B is correct

description: What is the correct order of steps to heapify a node in a max heap?
options: Compare parent with both children
Find the largest among parent and children
Swap parent with largest child if needed
Recursively heapify affected subtree

description: Which of these statements about heapify operation is correct?
options: Heapify always starts from the root node
Heapify operation takes O(n) time for a single node
Heapify maintains the complete binary tree property
Heapify must be performed on all nodes simultaneously

description: Match each heapify operation with its time complexity.
When building a heap, why do we start heapifying from the last non-leaf node?
options: It's more efficient than starting from the root
Leaf nodes are already valid heaps
It ensures the heap property is maintained
All of the above

description: Order these steps to build a max heap from an array.
options: Find the last non-leaf node
Start heapifying from last non-leaf node
Move towards root, heapifying each node
Complete when root is heapified

description: Match each operation with its heapify direction.
What is the time complexity of building a heap using the bottom-up approach?
options: O(n log n)
O(n)
O(log n)

description: Order the steps for inserting a new element into a heap.
options: Add element at the end of the heap
Compare with parent node
Swap if heap property is violated
Repeat until heap property is restored

description: Which operations require heapify during heap maintenance?
options: Only insertion
Only deletion
Both insertion and deletion
Neither insertion nor deletion

description: Match each heapify scenario with its appropriate action.
